Situation1: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They are about to enter the main prayer hall for Friday congregational worship.
Story: I was finishing my shift as a lifeguard, the chlorine tang still clinging to my skin. As I walked past the pool, I noticed a few chairs out of place—nothing major, but I knew the facility expected us to keep everything orderly. I glanced at my watch; Friday prayers would start soon, and I needed to change into my modest clothes before heading to the mosque. The expectation to maintain the pool area tugged at me, but so did the responsibility to dress appropriately and arrive on time for Jumu’ah. My uniform, a short-sleeved shirt and shorts, was far from suitable for the prayer hall. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one demanding immediate attention to detail, the other calling me to spiritual discipline and community. My heart pounded as I stood between the pool and the locker room, torn by the conflicting demands of duty and faith, unsure which expectation to meet first.
